title: the plays the thing five fabulous audio dramas not to miss this summer
story: With audio content exploding in popularity, a raft of gripping stories told by multiple narrators is just a few clicks awayA conversation can speak volumes and in the world of audio dramas, they often do. The audio drama – a piece of fiction told using several voices – is in the midst of a renaissance. Previously consigned to rare radio slots on rainy Sundays, audio dramas are now ubiquitous, buoyed by audience tastes for podcasts, and attracting some of the world’s most exciting writers and actors.These are professional, high-quality productions – think Netflix for your ears. And like Netflix, Audible has begun commissioning original audio dramas, making them free for members, putting an end to the bottleneck in which many creatives vie for one radio slot (and a broadcaster therefore has to pick the one with broadest appeal). Audio dramas run the gamut, whether you want a tear-jerking tragedy, an edge-of-your-seat thriller, or a heart-fluttering romance. With such variety, they make for perfect accompaniments to your summer holidays, whether you’ve got a long-haul backpacking trip planned, or a short and swift city break lined up.But with so many options, where do you begin?We picked out five of the best audio dramas from Audible, so you don’t have to. All you have to worry about is whether or not you can resist binge-listening your weekend away.The Child “My name is Simon. I’m 10 years old. I’m a serial killer.” So begins Sebastian Fitzek’s chilling tale of a boy who claims to have killed in a previous life. Set in Berlin, the story follows the child and the only people who believe his cryptic utterings – his mother and a lawyer she has hired. But when Simon’s knowledge leads to several bodies being discovered, the police start to suspect the lawyer. He must solve the crimes before the police put him in the frame, no matter what it takes. Fitzek is one of Germany’s most lauded crime-thriller writers and has seen his work translated into 20 languages. His talents are at their height in this intricate, spine-tingling adaptation. The fabulous narrators include Emilia Fox (Polanski’s The Pianist) and Rupert Penry-Jones (Spooks).Northanger Abbey If audio dramas are having a renaissance, Northanger Abbey might be the Sistine Chapel. A slick, star-studded adaptation of Jane Austen’s classic, this ambitious production has redefined audio storytelling – which is to be expected, given the cast. National treasure and Bafta award-winning actress Emma Thompson tops the bill, bringing Austen’s dry wit to life, while supporting performances from Lily Cole and Jeremy Irvine elevate the series to GOAT (greatest of all time) level. This coming-of-age story follows 17-year-old Catherine Morland through love, danger and intrigue, satirising the gothic tales that were popular at the time of writing, while taking a shrewd look at the British class system. Such skewering of high society feels as fresh as ever. Even those put off by historical drama will find joy in this.Neverwhere Nobody anticipated the impact the BBC’s 2013 adaptation of Neil Gaiman’s cult novel by the same name would have. Broadcast over six days, the production was a smash hit with Gaiman fans and non-fans alike, propelling the audio play into the public eye and showing just how exciting the form can be. Download to listen to Benedict Cumberbatch, David Harewood, James McAvoy and Natalie Dormer telling the story of Richard Mayhew, the unassuming Londoner who finds himself in London Below, a magical version of – and coexisting with – the real city, known as London Above. Originally conceived as a television series, Neverwhere lends itself to episodes, and so its separation into six parts feels natural and seamless. And on Audible it includes over 25 minutes of additional unbroadcasted material, including extended scenes, bloopers and outtakes.Rudyard Kipling’s The Jungle Book: The Mowgli Stories One for the slightly older kids (and also the parents), The Mowgli Stories brings together all of Kipling’s tales about the boy raised by animals in the jungle. Though the average listener might think they know all there is to know about Mowgli from the much-loved Disney film, his adventure takes many more twists and turns. This retelling of the timeless classic stays true to Kipling’s darker side and the well-known cast, including comedian Bill Bailey and actors Richard E Grant and Celia Imrie, make this one unforgettable audio drama. A must-listen for anyone who has seen the film, and a brilliant, truthful, introduction to the work of Kipling for those who haven’t.Locke &amp Key One of Audible’s first forays into commissioning original audio dramas is still among the most ambitious undertakings the form has seen. Locke &amp Key began life as a graphic novel – so translating the form from highly visual to solely audio was no small feat. To do so, Audible drafted in Locke &amp Key’s creators, Joe Hill and Gabriel Rodriguez, to ensure the adaptation stayed true to its dark, terrifying roots. And it worked, assisted no doubt by the voice of scream queen Tatiana Maslany (Orphan Black) and Haley Joel Osment of “I see dead people” fame. Locke &amp Key follows a family who, starting over after a tragedy, set themselves up in a quiet town that is also frequented by demons. A sharp production that will have you jumping out of your skin and sleeping with one eye open.Your first audiobook is free with a 30-day trial from Audible - £7.99 a month after 30 days. Renews automatically

title: swapra gala opera holland park le cid dorset opera review
story: Opera Holland Park, London Dorset Opera, Bryanston school, Blandford ForumA star-studded gathering of female opera talent provided the most harmonious of rallying cries. And a Massenet first in deepest DorsetOpera galas rarely merit reviews all those artists and works can read as dull inventory if you weren’t there. The inaugural concert of Swap’ra, involving some 150 singers, conductors, directors, stage managers and orchestral players – all women picture it – was a different matter, and formidably stylish too. The chance to witness Amanda Roocroft as a nostalgic Madame Larina from Tchaikovsky’s Eugene Onegin, or Catherine Wyn-Rogers and Anne Sophie Duprels, breaking our hearts in Puccini’s Suor Angelica, or Jennifer Johnston and Lee Bisset spinning their unwinding dreams in Britten’s The Rape of Lucretia gives you an idea of the quality.This new campaign (the full title is: Supporting Women and Parents in Opera) is a rallying cry to the opera industry to address gender disparity and to think laterally about how to give better support to singer-parents or carers (men too). Set up nine months ago by singers Anna Patalong, Madeleine Pierard, Kitty Whately and directors Sophie Gilpin and Ella Marchment, this is as thoughtful a pressure group as you could wish. Aware that issues of equality are at last being addressed, it’s giving a spirited push to speed up that change. A network, some bursaries, creche facilities (many singers find themselves paying for both coaching and childcare as they return to work), proper advance notice of when they are required for rehearsals: these are not frightening demands.The gala, introduced by Fiona Shaw, featured 17 scenes, directed by 10 different women and conducted by Jessica Cottis, Alice Farnham, Susannah Wapshott and Sonia Ben-Santamaria. I’ll save you the entire list, but the programme was perceptively devised, with recent music by Elena Langer, Roxanna Panufnik and Josephine Stephenson added to the mix. Among the co-founders, Madeleine Pierard as Bellini’s conflicted heroine Norma and Kitty Whately as a sexy Nerone in Monteverdi’s Pur ti miro shone. Perhaps the most delicious, effervescent scene of the evening was Anna Patalong leading a small and perfectly formed chorus as Giannetta in Donizetti’s L’elisir d’amore. Swap’ra was her idea, though she didn’t shout about it.Patalong was a memorable Tatyana two years ago in Dorset Opera’s Eugene Onegin. Last year she sang Marguerite there in Gounod’s Faust. No doubt many Swap’ra participants have benefited from the singular experience this tiny but vigorous company offers. An unstuffy summer camp rather than full-blown opera festival founded in 1974, Dorset Opera has established a reputation for staging rarities. This year, in rep with La bohème, the company gave the UK premiere of Massenet’s Le Cid (1885), about the medieval Castilian warrior hero.Frequently performed after its Paris premiere, the opera was shunted aside for no obvious reason after the first world war. Perhaps the taste for a story based on a gratuitous honour killing had soured, though its source material – Corneille’s 1637 tragicomedy – is impeccable, and many an opera plot is far more mawkish. Massenet’s score, which has a couple of familiar standalone arias and many grand choruses and ensembles, is a gorgeously vivid affair, saturated with emotion and without a speck of subtlety.Despite the music’s ceaseless fervour, the first two acts have saggy moments, but the last two acts roar by. It’s certainly worth doing, with challenging roles for Rodrigue (El Cid) and his lover, Chimène, taken with punch and intensity by Leonardo Capalbo and Lee Bisset. Paul Gay’s Don Diègue stood out among the well-taken supporting roles. The company’s music director, Jeremy Carnall, steered the performance with engaging gusto. Christopher Cowell’s production, designed by Steve Howell and updated to around the 1890s, caught the spirit of French operatic grandeur without fuss.The entire festival happens from scratch within 17 days, the two operas rehearsed concurrently in the week leading up to opening night. Dorset Opera has no public funding, and relies on box office, patrons, friends and charitable trusts. It gives full bursaries to young participants from the locality. Training and masterclasses, whether for musicians or in every aspect of stagecraft, wardrobe and props, are central. Well-known professional soloists, a 50-strong orchestra with a number of financially supported conservatoire students playing alongside professionals, and a large, youthful chorus (mostly aged 16 to 25) stay at Bryanston school.Performances take place at the school’s well-appointed Coade theatre, which has what you might call a generous acoustic. Under the persuasive artistic directorship of the international bass Roderick Kennedy, Dorset Opera’s standards, and its reach, are ever rising. Le Cid was a triumph, luckily, since luring a Massenet agnostic to a far-off region on a train-strike weekend could have ended badly. Instead, I’m a convert, or on the way.

title: theresa may and emmanuel macron hold brexit talks in france
story: French president’s office stresses there is no intention to undermine EU’s Michel BarnierIt was presented in the French press as a desperate Theresa May flying to the south of France to enlist the president’s help with Brexit.Fine food and wine served with a dose of politics was on the menu for a private dinner between Emmanuel Macron and his wife, Brigitte, and May and her husband, Philip, at the 13th-century Fort Brégançon.As the Mays’ convoy wound its way up the rocky road to the fort, the weather forecast provided an appropriate metaphor: a sunny start to the evening, storms expected later and clouds before sunset.Macron had travelled to the state summer house on the Mediterranean coast earlier in the day after his last council of ministers in Paris. The Mays arrived from Lake Garda in Italy, where they had been holidaying.May was counting on a personal approach to persuade Macron to soften EU resistance to her Brexit plan during their “informal” two-hour meeting.The prime minister, in a dark jacket and grey dress with a necklace of large green and white balls, and Macron, in a long-sleeved shirt and dark tie, sat side by side at a table installed in the interior courtyard of the fort. Their advisers were seated either side of the table. Behind them, a union jack, an EU flag and a French tricolore had been hastily installed.Footage of the meeting, relayed without sound, showed much nodding by both leaders.The 13th-century fortress at Brégançon on France’s Mediterranean coast is the presidential equivalent of Balmoral or Camp David.Fort de Brégançon sits on a tiny 35-metre-high rock off the coast, and has been the official summer retreat of French presidents since 1968.Not all of them have enjoyed the stay.Charles de Gaulle, the first president to stay there after requisitioning the site, left after one night complaining of small, uncomfortable beds and that he was plagued by mosquitos. He never returned.Georges Pompidou and his wife, Claude, liked holidaying at Brégançon in the late 1960s and early 1970s, installing the preferred huge white leather sofas and Plexiglas tables of the era.France’s first socialist president, François Mitterrand, held talks with the then German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, at the fort, but only actually stayed there once. Jacques Chirac was bored there, and Nicolas Sarkozy was pictured with his supermodel-turned-singer wife, Carla Bruni, there before they married. They did not return after.Brégançon, where Napoleon Bonaparte once stayed in the winter of 1793-94, fell into disrepair until it was decommissioned as a military base in 1919. Emmanuel Macron and his wife, Brigitte, have installed a €35,000 (£31,500) swimming pool, partly in an attempt to avoid the paparazzi who have snapped previous presidents and their partners on the fort’s private beach.Inside the fortress is said to be as austere as it is from the exterior and more like a country house than a presidential palace.Stéphane Bern, a French royal expert who visited the retreat, said: “It symbolises the prestige of the state. Everything there is sober and in good taste, without gold taps.” Kim WillsherWhatever May’s expectations, Macron made it clear beforehand that he would do nothing to undermine the efforts of the EU’s designated negotiator, Michel Barnier.“The plan was to go to Brégançon, which is to be a summer residence but also a place for working, and since May was finishing her vacation in Italy we proposed hosting her here,” a source in Macron’s office said.May was going to lay out “London’s position on the Brexit talks and its future relations with the EU,” the source said. “It will be the occasion to clarify this proposal and discuss the political context.”Macron has long dismissed attempts by British negotiators to ide and rule, refusing to become personally involved in the talks and potentially weaken Barnier’s hand.As a result, the Elysée said there would be no press conference or statement after the meeting. “There is absolutely no intention to speak in place of Michel Barnier,” the presidential source added.Pressure is growing on May to win allies on the continent after her Chequers plan prompted two of her ministers to resign in protest last month. She has just a few months before an agreement on Britain’s orce from the EU – due on 29 March 2019 – must be forged in principle ahead of a European summit in mid-October.France is seen as having taken a particularly hard line in the Brexit negotiations, especially on financial services, with Paris already expecting to get about 3,500 new banking jobs as leading players move operations out of London.The source in Macron’s office said Barnier had maintained that any Brexit accord “must conform with the economic interests of the 27 remaining EU members, and the president has always supported this as well.” But Macron also wanted to avoid a “messy orce”.On Friday the Bank of England governor, Mark Carney, said the possibility of a no-deal Brexit was “uncomfortably high” and such an outcome would lead to higher prices.He said the UK and EU should “do all things to avoid” a no-deal scenario, but added that the country’s financial system was in a position to be able to withstand such a shock.Asked by BBC Radio 4’s Today programme whether no-deal would be a disaster, he said: “It is highly undesirable. Parties should do all things to avoid it.”Pushed on what no-deal would mean, he said: “Disruption to trade as we know it.” He added: “As a consequence of that, a disruption to the level of economic activity, higher prices for a period of time.”

title: petition to remove mp ian paisley in north antrim criticised
story: Politicians censure ‘totally inadequate’ number of venues and pressure on postal votesThe electoral office in Northern Ireland has been accused of limiting the number of venues where North Antrim voters can sign a petition to remove Ian Paisley as an MP.Legislation allows for up to 10 centres to be set up in the constituency where a historic recall petition – which could oust the suspended Democratic Unionist party MP from his seat and force a byelection - can be signed over a six-week period.However, the electoral office has decided to set up only three in North Antrim, one of which will be located in a Unionist stronghold.The recall petition is the first of its kind and comes after Paisley was suspended last week. The parliamentary standards committee found him guilty of “serious misconduct” for failing to declare £50,000 of family holidays paid for by the Sri Lankan government in 2013.He then breached the rules on paid advocacy by writing to David Cameron in 2014 to lobby against a UN resolution on human rights abuses in Sri Lanka.Sinn Féin Northern Ireland assembly member Philip McGuigan said he had written to the electoral office urging it to put in place the maximum number of voting centres and introduce more flexible voting times.“The decision by the electoral office to locate petitions in only three locations in a large rural constituency like North Antrim is extremely disappointing and greatly reduces people’s ability to reject Ian Paisley’s disgraceful behaviour,” he said.“Some people will have to travel up to 20-25 miles to vote in one of these three centres and those who work outside of the constituency won’t have time to vote outside of working hours.”McGuigan said the number of voting centres for the Paisley petition was significantly lower compared with last year’s general election, when 94 ballot boxes were set up in 49 locations across the constituency.He added that some people would feel uncomfortable signing the petition at the Ballymoney centre because of the area’s strong unionist influence.The Ulster Unionist party leader, Robin Swann, agreed with McGuigan that the number of venues was “totally inadequate” for the size of the constituency.“I suspect that this very limited provision, both in terms of locations and timings, will lead to a larger than usual request for postal votes – and whether rightly or wrongly – this may well lead to accusations of voter identity abuse,” he said.However, the chief electoral officer, Virginia McVea, rejected the criticism. “I could have opened one venue or I could have opened 10,” she told the BBC’s Good Morning Ulster. “This runs for a lengthy period – six weeks – and during that period I determined that it would be reasonable to expect people to be able to reach these three venues. In addition there is a change in the law in relation to the postal application.“Anyone who chooses not to attend in person will be able to apply for the postal option and if their details are verified, can receive it within six weeks.”The petition will run from 8 August to 19 September and will be available for signing on weekdays from 9am to 5pm in centres in Ballymoney, Ballymena and Ballycastle.

title: england v india first test day four live
story: England took the five wickets they needed to wrap up an enthralling victory before lunch on day four at EdgbastonThat’s a nice place to leave it. A thrilling series opener, which, as Joe Root says, is a reminder that Test Match cricket is very much alive. At various stages through the second and third days both teams looked out of the contest before counterattacking with guts. Kohli’s solo hand with the bat was very nearly one for the ages (it probably was), as was Curran’s all-round explosion onto the international stage. Between times, champions like Ashwin and Anderson did as you would expect in a classic, Stokes and Ishant both superb with the ball as well. What a treat! Thanks for your company throughout the week. We’ll be with you again on the OBO for the Second Test at Lord’s, starting on Thursday. Bye for now from Edgbaston. Curran’s turn to chat. “Stokesey is one of the guys I look up to. I do have a strong competitive streak. I am the type of person who tries to play his natural game and not to worry what people think. It was just one of those days, it was pretty special. It feels surreal and I am trying to take it all in.” Asked about his father’s death and the influence on his cricket: “It has been pretty tough. I was still young when it did happen but we have a very strong family and we’re all close and our mum is very supportive of our cricket. I do take that into my game and take as many chances as I can and don’t really think about it too much, that’s when I play my best cricket. I learned that with two very competitive brothers growing up - not to give them anything.”Root press conference. “I am still trying to soak it in. I’m very proud of the group. The drive and determination from the players gives me a great amount of confidence going into the rest of the series.” “We always felt like we were in the game with the ball swinging throughout and we exploited that really well and made it difficult. Sometimes it is easy to criticise the batting groups but the way both seaming groups bowled was outstanding. It was a great surface that made for great Test cricket and it is important not to underestimate how good the bowling was.” On Edgbaston: “There were pockets of play yesterday when you could have thought that there were 60,000 people in the ground.”75,716 the final attendance across the four days. That’s better than 2016 when Pakistan were here, a Test that included both days of the weekend. You can be sure of one thing: when Australia visit for the opening Ashes rubber next year, there won’t be a spare seat. We have Joe Root and Sam Curran coming up in the press conference room shortly. Coming to you now from Ravi Ashwin’s press conference. “The bowlers in this Test Match were always in the game. So I thought we did compete really well and there are a lot of things to be upbeat about. Even when Umesh was batting our hopes were still alive. We are staying positive. This team has a belief we can win from any stage.”Sam Curran is man of the match! What a way to start an international career. On day two, he was the youngest English man to take a four-wicket bag in Test Match cricket, claiming three of those in eight balls as he raced through India’s top order. Then yesterday, he dragged England from 87-7 to respectability and, ultimately, a matchwinning lead with his dashing 63. Fantastic story.Kohli talks to BBC Test Match Special. “The series, I feel, is set up nicely. the fact that we didn’t play to our potential at all and went so close says everything about our side. I think it is going to be a very exciting and competitive series. We thought on day two at lunch we were nowhere near the game. It’s why it was such a great Test Match and why people enjoyed it so much.” Asked about his ton says it was “just like any other” because as captain his job becomes “all about dragging my team across the line.” But he does link that to how he was able to bat for so long. Another stat. Kohli faced only 16 of the 62 balls he was out there for this morning. Credit to Joe Root and the England bowlers in the part they played engineering that. Far easier said than done. Then Stokes came on.Match report on how it all went down this morning. The full package from Vic, Ali and Andy coming through the afternoon. Joe Root talks to Test Match Special. “Last night, that opening spell could have really been the difference in terms of swinging it in India’s favour but the boys didn’t let me down at all. We missed a few chances but we didn’t feel sorry for ourselves and that’s a great sign for us going forward.” He adds some nice words about Malan sticking at it in the slips, taking the clutch catch in the first over this morning to get England going. “It is set up beautifully,” he said of the series. “It is a great advert for the game and for Test Match Cricket.” Not wrong, Joe. Outstanding. A word for Rashid. He was given just one over last night and struck as soon as he was brought on this morning with a picture-perfect wrong’un. Can’t do a lot more than that. “I think that after all the noise on his selection it’s been justified,” adds AB Parker. Feels about right to me. Man of the Match? Probably Curran, innit? I mean, Kohli one of the all-time performances. But these gongs tend to go to the winning team. We’ll see shortly.Stick with the OBO through the post-match. We’ll have both captains coming up at the presentation and on radio. Cricket! Conventional final wicket. Stokes, with the second delivery of his 15th over, got one to spit at the Indian all-rounder off a length and he guided it into the hands of the veteran Cook who did the rest with a minimum of fuss before throwing the ball in the air in celebration. The end of one of the best Tests in modern memory. 54th over: India 162-9 (Pandya 31, Yadav 0) Target 194. Pandya digs leg spin. He takes them down day in, day out. This could be fascinating. He goes at the second offering, down to deep midwicket finding the gap but Jimmy Anderson makes a brilliant ing one-handed stop in front of the Hollies Stand faithful! Once upon a time 36-year-old quicks fielded exclusively with their boots but not JM Anderson. Pandya, still on strike having taken two from the stroke, gets a single down the ground from the fifth ball. So Umesh Yadav, once again, has one ball to see off. In comes the silly point right under his eyeline but the Rashid leg break is short enough for the no. 11 to get back and defend with a straight blade. Again, really well done. Do we have another twist coming? 53rd over: India 159-9 (Pandya 28, Yadav 0) Target 194. Stokes to Pandya, again with the field well spread. “Pandya is going to have to gamble to get down the other end at the end of this over,” says Vaughan. He considers taking one to deep backward point from the third ball before thinking better of it. Nor from the fourth when driving to long-off. Cat and mouse, rinse and repeat. He does take the run from the fifth, to extra cover. Umesh Yadav has one Ben Stokes delivery to get through. Can the fast bowler bat with the bravery of Michael Kasprowicz in 2005 at this venue? Make no mistake, brave he was that day. He does here, right in behind it. Well batted! “What a time to take over the OBO and to remind us of the need to get test cricket back on free to air telly during another Edgbaston nail-biter,” writes Brian Withington. “Good job they didn’t have DRS back in 2005 or we’d be remembering that one as a famous Aussie victory.” 52nd over: India 158-9 (Pandya 27, Yadav 0) Target 194. Just a slip and a short leg, no silly point or leg slip. Rashid brings him forward with three consecutive leg breaks to begin. All nicely flighted. When does the wrong’un come? Not from the fourth: another conventional ball turning away, defended competently. Then beats him with another, this turning sharply! Last ball of the over and it is a full toss. Umesh Yadav does well to knock it out to deep point but, of course, they decide to stay put. Maiden. Phew.51st over: India 158-9 (Pandya 27, Yadav 0) Target 194. Stokes to Pandya, with six men out to begin the over. The visiting all-rounder tries to launch a drive but miscues to deep cover. They decline the single. “Wherever you are in the field for England now you have a chance of a catch,” Michael Vaughan says on TMS. “Who wants it?” Not wrong: he is going to do what he does best and attempt to hit his country to victory. Drives classically to long-off from the fourth ball of the over and he doesn’t run even though there might have been two on offer. In comes the field with two balls to come, Stokes bangs it in short of a length, smacking into the thigh pad. Can he keep the strike from the final ball? “I think it is worth having the third man up for the final ball” says Vaughan. Root doesn’t. Pandya isn’t looking for one though, he’s up and over mid-off for four! So he’s taken the runs instead of the strike. More to the point, Rashid will get a look at Umesh Yadav, the India no. 11, who is yet to face a delivery. Yes it is! It is good! Ishant Sharma didn’t pick the googly and Rashid is in the book with the final ball of his first over this morning. It is a wonderful bowling change from Joe Root. It was a gamble and it has paid off BIG TIME. England need one wicket to win.IS SHARMA OUT LBW? We are going upstairs to find out! Rashid is on and beating him with the wrong’un. Given not out but it looks good... What a time to join you. Thanks Tim for yielding the floor to me as we share the final stanza of this riveting match. I tell you what, if the ECB are determined to “add a fresh tactical dimension” the sport in this country, they could do worse than getting Tests back onto free to air telly ASAP. Anyway, that’s a hill for me to die on another day. When they return from drinks my vantage point of Sam Curran could not be any better: directly over his arm in the front row of the press box. Will the young man stick the landing on his magnificent Edgbaston outing and slip another inducker through the gate? Let’s soak this in together reach me in the usual ways. 49th over: India 152-8 (Pandya 23, Sharma 9) Stokes resumes, and concedes his first run as Hardik, showing some faith in his partner, takes a single. Then a poke from Ishant goes for four to the vacant third man. Come on Joe, gotta have a third man for the tail, it’s the only place they ever hit it on a surface like this. And then Ishant does it again, fending off a bouncer. Ten off the over! And there’s a bit of argy-bargy, as if we needed more spice. India need just 42 more, and it’s over to Adam Collins for the next and very possibly last hour. Thanks for your company: it’s been huge.Here’s Kim Thonger. “I’m sitting outside Waitrose with the dog, listening to TMS through my hearing aid while SWMBO potters inside. When Stokes got Kohli I leapt into the air and now there’s a clutch of senior citizens eyeing me very strangely. I think one of them has called an ambulance for me.”48th over: India 142-8 (Pandya 22, Sharma 0) Now Curran comes on, and there’s a rather pointless delay to check a bump ball, grabbed by Jennings at third-no-fourth slip. Not out. India need 52 England need two wickets.A follow-up from Kola Cielencina (42nd over). “It’s not that I dislike OBO coverage it’s superb. You guys are all round good eggs who really make my cricketing days...but just wanted some sound effects ie that ball thudding into Kohli’s pads!!...Sitting here now watching for ‘wicket’ in bold type out of the corner of my eye.. Keep up the sterling work and many thanks again.” It’s our pleasure.47th over: India 141-8 (Pandya 21, Sharma 0) So Stokes starts with a double-wicket maiden. Fantastic. The ball to Kohli was hitting leg stump the ball to Shami, delivered from much the same spot above Stokes’s left ear, was jagging away. That’s the match, you’d assume. But let’s have one more twist, shall we? And Hardik, the main run-maker this morning, can score fast.“Morning Tim.” Morning Adam Roberts. “I didn’t quite make the 5.00 start here in Cayman and was beginning to lose a bit of heart. Has Ben Stokes just given me that most dangerous of presents - hope?” He has – twice over.Stokes does it again! He angles it in, moves it away, and that’s two in his first over. Immense stuff from Stokes. But it’s not over yet. He’s made 200 in the game, but now he’s missed a straight one. What a bowling change from Root. England are favourites now.Anderson comes off! But it’s Stokes, not Curran. Anything could happen.46th over: India 141-6 (Kohli 51, Pandya 21) Virat who? Hardik is looking to win this by himself. Facing Broad and meeting the ball far earlier than in the first innings, he plays another ravishing straight drive, and another clip to midwicket, both for four. This wasn’t in the script, which makes it all the more riveting. India need only 53 now. England need a wicket, desperately – but does Root, still finding his feet as captain, have the ability to conjure one up?An email from a football fan. “There’s not a pub open this early in town with the cricket on,” says Martin Maloney, “as I do my, ahem, premature preparation for the Cobblers’ game against Lincoln. This is riveting coverage, as I settle for pubs without cricket. As more of a t20 man and baseball player these days, it’s good to be reminded of how great Test cricket can be.” 45th over: India 133-6 (Kohli 51, Pandya 13) Anderson continues, as he probably will till the end of time. Another single for Kohli, on the leg side for a change, before Hardik clips for three through midwicket, and then Kohli glances for four to reach another superb fifty. Anderson raps him on the pad but the appeal is half-hearted as the impact is outside the line Kohli pokes away from his body but the ball drops short of the widest slip. For the first time today, India are getting on top. They need 61 now.44th over: India 125-6 (Kohli 46, Pandya 10) What’s this? A four? Broad goes full and Hardik sees the chance for a straight drive. Shot of the morning, not that there has been any competition: Kohli has faced only nine balls, thanks to his penchant for singles. Broad bounces back by beating Hardik with a short one – too short to take the edge. Get Curran on!43rd over: India 121-6 (Kohli 46, Pandya 6) Anderson beats Hardik with his version of the textbook ball, seaming up and jogging away, but it’s six inches too short to take the edge. India need 73.“Great match and great coverage,” says David Murray. Thank you. “There’s been a lot of talk about how brilliant Kohli has been and rightly so. But if England had held their chances or if he’d nicked one of the many balls that beat him then he would have been out for a low score, so just how brilliant can he have been? Root meanwhile played excellently but was run out by his partner and his innings is therefore again seen as a relative failure. There’s a lot of luck in these things.” Very true. “Also, how ironic that India’s superior fielding and running between the wickets should be the main difference between the teams.” Better use of spin, too – a weapon to open the bowling, not a last resort. 42nd over: India 120-6 (Kohli 46, Pandya 5) Pandya calls for a tight single to mid-on and for a moment the crowd think there’s going to be a run-out, but he makes it. The crowd, so vociferous last night, have been a bit morning-after today.41st over: India 118-6 (Kohli 46, Pandya 3) Kohli, facing Anderson, again takes an early single, getting his nose right over the ball and easing into the gap at backward point. Shut that door! 40th over: India 117-6 (Kohli 45, Pandya 3) Broad beats Pandya with a ball from the coaching book, pitching on off and seaming away, and stays fifth-stump-isa to stop those clips to leg. A maiden.“I may be doing both a disservice here,” says Richard Liddle, “but Curran reminds me of Dominic Cork. Both very competitive and both get more out of themselves than their talents suggest.” Cork made all the difference against West Indies at Lord’s in 2000, when England were in just the tight corner that India find themselves in now.39th over: India 117-6 (Kohli 45, Pandya 3) More tip-and-run from Kohli, facing his first ball from Anderson this morning. Then Pandya, getting across onto off stump, calmly works a couple of straight balls into the leg side for a two and a single. India need 77 and the sun is still out. Is it cowardly to pray for clouds?38th over: India 113-6 (Kohli 44, Pandya 0) Root goes with Broad at the other end. Kohli, who is looking twitchy rather than imperious, takes a tip-and-run single into the covers – England may need a short extra to shut that door. Broad beats Pandya outside off. Both the old boys have been right on the spot.37th over: India 112-6 (Kohli 43, Pandya 0) Anderson starts with three dots, in the channel, before Karthik picks up two through the vacant gully – Root has posted a first, second and fourth slip, but no third man (swiftly corrected). Then comes the wicket. Full marks to Anderson, and to Root for keeping faith with Malan.They’re double-checking in case the ball touched the ground, but it looks fine. Yes, out.First blood to England! And it’s Malan, of all people, who takes a sharp low catch at second slip.To Dinesh Karthik, who batted well last night. He’s standing outside his crease, like Kohli. Jerusalem is ringing out, and a group of five friends are just passing through security. They’ve come as bananas. An email from John Starbuck. “It looks as if Ishant Sharma has another career in prospect,” he reckons, “as a Crazy World of Arthur Brown tribute act.”And here’s Gary Naylor, with a gloss on my game plan. “I feel England need 4 slips and a gully for Kohli early on to attack him full and well outside off stump. He’ll want to assert himself and he won’t be happy letting the ball go. He’ll also want the strike. To other batsmen, such a line would be negative - not to him!” What do you reckon? And how nervous are you? Both these teams have supporters who tend to see the glass half-empty. The weather is on India’s side at the moment, with the sun shining. But the Met Office has some cloud cover arriving at 11am, right on cue, before the sun returns at noon. Michael Holding, doing the pitch report, can see “no tinge of green”. But there are a few cracks...Within this deliciously tight contest, an even tighter one is going on – between Kohli and the rest of India. In the match as a whole, Kohli has 192 runs for once out. His team-mates, or subjects, have 170 for 14 times out. If you give them Extras, which seems only fair, the score is 192-all. Kohli also dismissed England’s best batsman, Joe Root, twice – first with a direct hit, then by posting a leg slip to Ashwin. If India win, it won’t be hard to work out who is the man of the match.

title: beverley knight defends her casting as emmeline pankhurst
story: The singer is to play the suffragette leader at the Old Vic theatre in SeptemberBeverley Knight has hit out at critics of her casting as Emmeline Pankhurst in a new musical by pointing to the ubiquity of white actors playing characters of other ethnicities.Knight will play the leader of the British suffragette movement, with Genesis Lynea taking the titular role of Sylvia Pankhurst, Emmeline’s daughter, in the play, which opens next month at the Old Vic theatre.Responding to a detractor on Twitter who suggested that she did not have the right skin colour for the role, Knight tweeted: Following in the footsteps of Hamilton, a hip-hop retelling of the life of the American founding father Alexander Hamilton, Sylvia tells the story of the campaign for women’s suffrage through a combination of dance, hip-hop, soul and funk. On BBC One’s The One Show on Wednesday, Knight said that the casting of Sylvia was a reflection of progress in theatre. “It’s just interesting that 100 years later, here’s me as a black woman playing the role of someone who was white. “It’s just kind of marking the direction of where theatre is going – the ersity, the inclusivity, and the fact that the music is much more street and modern and contemporary. I think Emmeline would like it.“Most of the show is sung. It’s at the Old Vic, so people who go and see shows at the Old Vic would expect something a little more traditional. This is anything but. I’m not rapping, but I am speaking rhythmically as well as singing the way that people know me to sing.“There’s a lot of hip-hop, there’s a lot of R&ampB, there’s a lot of funk. It’s telling this seismic story in a really fresh way. It’s glorious, it really is.”Written by Kate Prince and Priya Parmar, with original music by Josh Cohen and DJ Walde, Sylvia tells the story of the sometimes difficult relationship between the Pankhursts. In an earlier interview, Prince, whose company ZooNation will produce the piece, said: “Politics and families are a tricky combination, and in the case of the Pankhursts, it severed ties between them. Ultimately we are telling the story of the price each of the Pankhurst family paid for their political purpose.”Sylvia is at the Old Vic from 3-22 September.

title: class review traverse edinburgh abbey theatre iseult golden david horan
story: Traverse, EdinburghA parent-teacher meeting becomes a microcosm for privilege and exclusion in a subtle, well-acted three-handerThe entrance of Sarah Morris’s Donna is delayed. “I thought I’d be called,” she says as she stumbles apologetically into Mr McCafferty’s classroom. This is not her territory and she doesn’t know the rules. Despite being 29, when she wants to ask a question she instinctively raises her hand.Stephen Jones as her estranged husband, Brian, is scarcely more confident, though he has a bullish swagger to cover his insecurity. Given the chance, he’ll scrawl on the blackboard in the only gesture of defiance left open to him, a pathetic attempt to assert control. In Iseult Golden and David Horan’s fraught and quarrelsome three-hander, this primary school represents a schism. It is not just about the educated and the unread, but the haves and the have-nots. In a society organised to benefit the better off, the school is the site of class warfare.And yet Will O’Connell’s McCafferty is the kind of liberal-minded teacher any parent would want. Even the children say they like him. He is attentive, patient and game for a laugh. But whether he knows it or not, he is also a man whose middle-class privilege puts him in control. In a play that inhabits grey areas, his well-intentioned attempts to do the right thing can also look like interfering. It just depends on whether your perspective is from the top down or the bottom up.What he has on his side is language. Instead of “gap”, he goes for “disparity” he speaks with ease of “percentiles”. No problem if you speak the jargon. If not, it is the language of exclusion. Reacting to a volley of abuse from an angry Brian, McCafferty has some justification in saying the language used is “not acceptable for this meeting” – except it reinforces the idea that the only acceptable language is his.This parents’ meeting, ostensibly to discuss the unsteady progress of Donna and Brian’s son Jayden – they might call it a problem with reading and writing McCafferty talks about literacy and learning differences – turns into a territorial war of attrition. Thanks to their experiences of being educated in the same school, Donna and Brian have learned to be suspicious of any intervention that could disadvantage Jayden. They know what it’s like to be rejected, undermined and relegated to the back of the class, and instinctively resist any proposal that could harm their son in the same way.The play doesn’t make it easy the issues of addiction, neglect and broken families that creep into this classroom in a deprived area of Dublin are none of the teacher’s doing. He’s just a small cog in a wider systemic failure – and it is a system that ultimately fails him, too. The play stops short of apportioning blame – nobody comes out of it well – in preference to exploring the uncertain territory where prejudice, damage and failed intentions collide. Directed by the playwrights, Class is tremendously acted in a series of fast-cut scenes that chop between the parents’ evening and the homework club where Jayden and his classmate Kaylie try in vain to make up for lost time. Doubling roles, Morris and Jones capture the children’s combination of physical freedom and emotional vulnerability just as they strike a perfect balance of defensiveness and anger in the adults. There are no answers in this classroom, but many provocative questions.

title: on the exhale review traverse edinburgh festival 2018 polly frame martin zimmerman
story: Traverse, EdinburghAs a bereaved mother, Polly Frame is consumed by thoughts of revenge as Martín Zimmerman’s mesmerising tale of a school massacre hits homeIn the Alice in Wonderland logic of the National Rifle Association, “guns don’t kill people, people do”. It’s an aphorism that pretends to be revelatory but is actually the opposite. At best it is a deflection, at worst irresponsible. The 7,074 people who died in US shootings in the first half of this year do not have the privilege of debating whether they were slaughtered by man or machine. As Eddie Izzard once said, “I think the gun helps.”Martín Zimmerman’s On the Exhale, first seen in 2017 and now given its UK premiere in a focused production by Christopher Haydon for China Plate and Audible, is an attempt to get under the skin of a debate that tells you more about America’s fraught relationship with its history and constitution than it does about reasoned argument. In this story about a bereaved mother reeling from the shock of a school massacre, assault rifle and shooter merge to become one and the same. The gun is an extension of the person carrying it.As the playwright presents it, the student with a pistol under his belt is transformed. Typically, the weapon takes wounded male privilege (because it is so often thus) and replaces it with power. It’s a power that imbalances every relationship. No one will contradict, still less confront, the person in the room with the capacity to gun you down.Dreaming of taking revenge after the shooting, the bereaved woman becomes so transfixed by the rifle she buys (a three-minute transaction requiring no more than a driver’s license) that it becomes a living presence. Venturing into the heart of darkness, she realises she “can’t be trusted to control herself around machines of such seductive power”.Performed in a country where the gun lobby has no sway, the play risks simply confirming our guns-are-bad prejudices. It sidesteps this thanks to the intensity of Zimmerman’s second-person script, which never takes you quite where you expect, and the mesmerising performance of Polly Frame. Still, matter-of-fact and measured, her delivery is gripping in its economy and hits home like a bullet.

title: the greatest play in the history of the world review julie hesmondhalgh traverse edinburgh kershaw
story: Traverse, EdinburghJulie Hesmondhalgh’s superb turn as narrator lights up these comic tales about the universal significance of loveIn festivals past, the Traverse has showcased a beguiling series of monologues by Daniel Kitson. At their best, they were masterpieces of daring storytelling that painted the small details of everyday lives with such care they seemed to take on universal weight.To see Kitson this year, you have to stay up late for a sold-out run at the Stand comedy club, but the Traverse is satisfying the need for the romantic and the whimsical – with a side helping of cosmic significance – in Ian Kershaw’s science-fiction fantasy about an apparently accidental romance that turns out to have been written in the stars.As the Voyager space probes venture into the solar system carrying Carl Sagan’s recoded anthology of human culture (“People having a good time. People cramming it all in”), we find ourselves among the ordinary shops and houses of a certain Preston Road where, one morning at 4.40am, time has inexplicably stood still. That’s when the directionless Tom wakes up and, having inadvertently caught the eye of his neighbour Sara across the street, decides to write a play called The Greatest Play in the History of the World … Meanwhile, another set of neighbours are embarking on a scientific adventure that will draw him and Sara eternally together.If the piece doesn’t quite achieve the shiver-down-the-spine resonance it aspires to, straining a little too hard to turn the Voyager journeys into a metaphor for universal love, it is nonetheless a funny and charming tapestry of tales that holds your imagination before it reveals its time-travelling secrets.What makes it special, in Raz Shaw’s good-looking production, is the superb performance of Julie Hesmondhalgh as the unnamed narrator, meticulously colouring in the stories of neighbours, friends and love rivals whom she identifies by the footwear she finds in the shoeboxes of Naomi Kuyck Cohen’s set – and also by the shoes she borrows from a willing audience. Looking us in the eye, the Coronation Street and Broadchurch star gives a big-hearted performance that is as warm and generous as it is precise in its narrative control.

title: this is the title review ima idouzee edinburgh festival 2018 dance base
story: Dance Base, EdinburghIma Iduozee slinks and swoops with insouciant ease in this solo piece, but patchy sound design and a ponderous self-indulgence hold the show backHe pivots on his head with insouciant ease. One moment he’s in casual repose on the floor, looking earthbound and ordinary, the next he has weightlessly transitioned into a b-boy freeze, suspending his bodyweight on one arm, his legs knotted above his head or split like compass needles. Moments like these are exhilarating to behold, but the thrill soon subsides. For all Iduozee’s obvious facility, his feats of spiralling speed and precision are overshadowed by a frustrating tendency to crouch in the corner, occasionally flicking beads of sweat off his pate into the footlights. He may well be generating profound thoughts at this point, but it doesn’t really translate. An unfortunate sense of self-indulgence settles over proceedings (the piece’s grandiosely meta name doesn’t help matters).The fitfulness of the physicality is exacerbated by the weirdly patchy nature of the sound design. Initial bursts of thrumming electronica and crackling feedback have the awkward, glitchy quality of a school PA system on the blink, so it’s a relief when clacking typewriter keys and watery gushing sounds take over. Iduozee can easily impress and compel, but he needs less ponderous fare than this.
